title: 110_hr3133
content: The Act may be cited as the "Financial Literacy for Homeowners Act". The Congress finds that expanded access to credit has led to high homeownership rates, but some lenders engage in predatory practices, making it costly for low-income families. Borrowers with fair credit can get prime loans with low rates, while those with poor credit get subprime loans with higher rates and fees. Predatory lending in the mortgage market involves high interest rates, excessive fees, and unfair terms, particularly affecting minority neighborhoods and stripping away wealth accumulated over decades. Predatory loans with unjustifiably high interest rates, excessive fees, and unreasonable terms have grown rapidly in minority neighborhoods, stripping away wealth accumulated over a lifetime. Cash-poor homeowners in underserved communities are often victimized by lenders offering high-interest home equity loans with hidden fees, leading to struggles in meeting mortgage payments. The joint report by the Department of Housing and Urban Development and the Department of the Treasury urged Congress to adopt legislation to curb predatory home mortgage lending by restricting abusive terms, improving consumer disclosures, and prohibiting harmful sales practices. The joint report urged Congress to adopt legislation to restrict abusive terms and conditions on high-cost loans, improve consumer literacy and disclosures, prohibit harmful sales practices in mortgage markets, and establish predatory lending as a factor in evaluations for the Community Reinvestment Act of 1977. The report also proposed a four-point plan to address predatory lending practices, including requiring lenders to recommend home mortgage counseling, disclose credit scores to borrowers, and provide timely and accurate information on loan costs and terms. The government agencies are involved in addressing predatory lending issues to reduce lenders using high-pressure sales techniques and misleading borrowers. This threatens the work of nonprofit organizations in improving distressed neighborhoods. More assistance is needed for borrowers with predatory loans. Predatory lending poses a threat to the efforts of nonprofit organizations and government agencies working to improve distressed neighborhoods. More support is needed to help borrowers with predatory loans, educate consumers about the risks of home loans, and guide them to appropriate resources for assistance. Grant program established for education and counseling on predatory lending. The Secretary of the Treasury may provide grants to States, local governments, and nonprofits for eligible anti-predatory lending activities, including education programs to inform vulnerable consumers about unfair lending practices related to home loans. The Secretary of the Treasury may provide grants for anti-predatory lending activities, including education programs on unfair lending practices related to home loans for low-income borrowers and senior citizens. This includes counseling programs and referral services for homeowners and prospective homeowners. To be eligible for a grant under this section, a State, unit of general local government, or nonprofit organization must submit an application to the Secretary for services that provide referrals to education and counseling programs or appropriate agencies handling consumer complaints related to predatory lending practices in home loans. To be eligible for a grant under this section, a State, unit of general local government, or nonprofit organization must submit an application to the Secretary for services related to home loans or investigating possible violations of law. The maximum grant amount is $1,000,000 per fiscal year, and the Secretary will oversee the selection of applicants. The Secretary will oversee the selection of applicants for grants up to $1,000,000 per fiscal year from States, local governments, and nonprofits. The Secretary will establish a toll-free telephone number for predatory lending complaints, provide information and assistance to borrowers, and coordinate with organizations. Additionally, a Predatory Lending Advisory Council will be formed. Established in the Department of the Treasury is a Predatory Lending Advisory Council (referred to as the "Council") to advise the Secretary on policies and issues related to predatory and unscrupulous lending practices in home loans. The Council will consist of 13 members appointed by the Secretary, including representatives of community-based organizations and officials of State agencies. The Predatory Lending Advisory Council advises the Secretary on predatory lending practices in home loans. It includes members who educate consumers, State officials, private homeowners familiar with mortgages, and representatives from the real estate industry. Members serve two-year terms, with initial members serving staggered terms of one or two years. The Predatory Lending Advisory Council consists of 3 members from the private real estate industry, serving two-year terms with initial members having staggered terms. Members serve without compensation but receive travel expenses. The Secretary designates a chairperson, and meetings are called by the chairperson, with a minimum of 3 meetings required. The Predatory Lending Advisory Council, as per sections 5702 and 5703 of title 5, United States Code, will meet at least 3 times a year and can hold public hearings. The Council advises the Secretary on grant program criteria and toll-free telephone number operations. The Predatory Lending Advisory Council advises the Secretary on grant program criteria, toll-free telephone number operations, and coordination of activities to prevent predatory lending practices. They also conduct a study on the root causes of default and foreclosure of home loans. The Predatory Lending Advisory Council conducts a study on the root causes of default and foreclosure of home loans, using empirical data to make recommendations for consumer protection legislation. SEC. 6. DEFINITIONS. The term "home loan" under this Act refers to a loan secured by residential property, including home equity lines of credit and home improvement loans. The term "nonprofit organization" is defined as per the Cranston-Gonzalez National Affordable Housing Act. The term "predatory or unscrupulous lending practice" includes making loans solely based on home equity without considering the borrower's ability to repay, leading to unaffordable obligations. Predatory lending practices include making loans solely based on home equity without considering the borrower's ability to repay, leading to unaffordable obligations. This can also involve inducing borrowers to refinance repeatedly and charging additional points and fees, even when it may not be in the borrower's best interest. Predatory lending practices involve inducing borrowers to refinance repeatedly and charging extra fees, even if it's not in their best interest. The term "State" includes several States, Puerto Rico, the District of Columbia, and other U.S. territories. The term "unit of general local government" refers to various political subdivisions within a State. Authorization of Appropriations: $55,000,000 authorized annually for fiscal years 2008-2012. Limits set for sections 4 and 5 funding. Regulations may be issued by the Secretary to implement the Act.
